intro: Dianthus seguieri var. controversus, commonly known as the rock campion, is a perennial flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It features basal rosettes of velvety, dark green leaves and produces clusters of pink or red, bilaterally symmetrical flowers. The plant is drought-tolerant and thrives in well-drained, rocky or sandy soils. It blooms from spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its hardy nature and ornamental value, it is often cultivated in rock gardens and as a border plant.
